raw_comment:
What do you notice?
- majority of the data points scatter above y=x
- countries with higher HDI (human development index > 7~8) tend to have a much larger percentage of youth believing that the world is getting better than the 40+ generation
What do you wonder?
- Causation of the reason why young people tend to believe that the world will become a better place, its relationship with the education & shifts in Overton window in individual countries.
- Connection/ Causation relationship of this graph and other factors such as GDP per capita growth rate, rate increase of life expectancy etc.
How does this relate to you and your community?
- Reflection in life: how the elder generations tend to be pessimistic about global warming, while the youngsters are positive in seeking solutions of such things.
Headline:
- Optimistic vs Pessimistic, Young vs Old
ace_sentences: Many data points are above the line y = x.
Some countries have a high HDI.
A country has a high HDI if the HDI of the country is greater than 7.

In countries with a high HDI, the percentage of youth who believe that the world is getting better is larger than the percentage of people who are 40 or older who believe that the world is getting better.
I wonder about the cause of the belief of young people that the world will become a better place.
I wonder about a relationship between this belief and education in a country.
I wonder about a relationship between this belief and shifts in the Overton window in a country.
I wonder about a connection between this graph and the GDP per capita growth rate of a country.
I wonder about a connection between this graph and the rate of increase of life expectancy in a country.
In my life, elder generations tend to be pessimistic about global warming.
In my life, young people tend to be positive about seeking solutions for global warming.
The headline is: Optimistic vs Pessimistic, Young vs Old.
